title: Once a judgment is entered in a unlimited civil action, what does the judgment creditor do to collect?
question: The court issued a judgment in favor of the plaintiff in an unlimited civil case (17K) against the defendant in Calif. What is the best wayto goto collect the debt if the debtor owns property and does he have to wait 30 days to do this. ALSO, does the fee waiver the plaintiff was granted originally cover this stage of the process in filing of documents, process serving etc..or does the plaintiff have to pay?
answers:
The judgement creditor will attempt to collect on the debt after the judgement is entered. Was this a default judgement? The filing fee MAY only cover the initially filings (complaint or answer). Do you have a copy of the filing fee waiver document?

Some of these questions can be answered in more detail with the supplementation of more facts. Feel free to contact our offices and mention that you are calling regarding your AVVO posting for a free consultation. Good luck!

Here is a blog article I wrote a few years ago on the topic: http://blog.chs-law.com/2006/07/collecting-california-judgments.html.

The filing fees have gone up, but the basics are still the same.

The California courts website offer tips for collecting a small claims judgment (http://www.courts.ca.gov/1014.htm), but those procedures differ for collecting an unlimited claim judgment. The Rutter Group's "Enforcing Judgments and Debts" is a good practice guide. You should be able to find it in your local public law library (Whittier Law School Library in Costa Mesa).

The deadline for appealing an unlimited civil judgment is 60 days from the day you mail Notice of Entry of Judgment, or 180 days from the date of entry of judgment if you don't mail the Notice. However, you may begin recording liens and requesting levies now. If the defendant files an appeal, then all your collection efforts will be stayed.

Of course, you can hire a collections attorney to enforce/collect the judgment for you. Some attorneys will offer you a choice between a contingent attorney fee (a fee based on a percentage of the amounts actually collected) and an hourly fee.

Good luck.
